subject: Re: [junit] Testing a class with private constructor
msgSnippet: You cannot subclass a class with a private constructor, since the superclass constructor will not be visible for the implicit constructor to call.  The

You cannot subclass a class with a private constructor, since the
superclas=
s constructor will not be visible for the "implicit"
constructor to call.  =
The compiler will choke on it.

- rob

On 6/23/05, jason r tibbetts <tibbet=
tj@...> wrote:
> mcgeejdw2004 wrote:
> > I have a class with=
 a private constructor and a static factory method
> > that returns an inst=
ance.  I would like to run a Junit test that tests
> > a few methods of thi=
s class but I do not want to make the constructor
> > public and I would ra=
ther avoid creating a mock object to pass to the
> > static factory because=
 this could take some time to develop.  What is
> > the best way to handle =
this?
> 
> JUnit-addons (http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons) has =
a
> PrivateAccessor class that allows you to do just what it says, although=

> I can't tell from the documentation (or state from experience) how you
>=
 can invoke the constructor with it.
> 
> Or you can subclass the class, gi=
ve it a public constructor, and test that.
